title: Scott Bessent, Trump's unexpected gunslinger at the US Treasury
summary: The 62-year-old financier, who learned the ropes with George Soros's teams in London, is pushing, as the head of the US Treasury, the policy of destabilization advocated by the White House.

title: Chahinez Daoud: trial of "archetypal" femicide begins
summary: In 2021, Mounir Boutaa shot his 31-year-old former partner Chahinez Daoud, whom he'd abused for years, before dousing her with gas and setting her on fire. The crime with national repercussions in France embodies the police and judicial dysfunctions that mark femicide cases.

title: US, Russia talks on Ukraine ceasefire end after 12 hours
summary: While the talks took place at a luxury hotel in Saudi Arabia, nearly 90 people including 17 children were wounded in a missile attack on Sumy in northeastern Ukraine.

title: Oscar-winning Palestinian director is attacked by Israeli settlers and detained, activists say
summary: Palestinian co-director of Oscar-winning doc 'No Other Land,' Hamdan Ballal, was attacked by West Bank settlers and arrested by the Israeli army, according to his colleague and an NGO.

title: White House confirms journalist was accidentally added to group chat planning Yemen strikes
summary: 'The Atlantic' magazine's editor-in-chief Jeffrey Goldberg revealed that he had hours of advance notice of strikes against Yemen's Houthi rebels on March 15 after he was 'inadvertently' added to a group chat on Signal.

title: When Snoopy meets fashion, a coat that's doggone cute
summary: The philosophical beagle celebrates his 75th birthday with an exhibition in Paris focusing on his links to fashion. Among the pieces on show is a 1989 coat made of stuffed animals in his likeness, designed by Jean-Charles de Castelbajac, who introduced cartoon culture to ready-to-wear.

title: South Korea faces violent forest fires
summary: Nearly 7,700 hectares have burned in three days in the southeast of the country, leaving four people dead and six injured.

title: 'Many Silicon Valley figures saw Donald Trump's election as an opportunity'
summary: In an interview with 'Le Monde,' sociologist Olivier Alexandre explains that the rallying of tech leaders around Trump is linked to tensions with the Democratic camp and the Biden administration.

title: Gérard Depardieu's sexual assault trial starts
summary: The 76-year-old French actor's trial started on Monday morning. He is accused of sexually abusing two women on a 2021 film shoot. Despite having faced a slew of allegations, this is the first case to come to trial.

title: In Turkey, a human tide in the streets for a fifth evening in support of Ekrem Imamoglu, jailed mayor of Istanbul
summary: Millions of people took part in a vote on Sunday organized by the main opposition party, the CHP, to nominate their candidate for the 2028 presidential election. The clear winner is currently in prison.

title: Netanyahu's government continues to bulldoze through state apparatus and Gaza Strip
summary: The cabinet of the most radical government in the country's history passed a no-confidence motion against the attorney general. In Gaza, the symbolic threshold of 50,000 deaths was crossed, according to the enclave's Ministry of Health.

title: Seven people arrested for giving Nazi salutes during the French-Croatia match in Paris
summary: According to a police source, around 10 Croatian supporters gave Nazi salutes at the start of the match during their national anthem. Croatian supporters again gave Nazi salutes during the first half.

title: Trump threatens 25% tariff on countries that buy oil, gas from Venezuela
summary: The American president has also begun to deport immigrants accused of being members of the South American Tren de Aragua gang, who illegally crossed into the United States.

title: Journalists in Russia: 'It's much more dangerous today than it was under perestroika'
summary: Russian media outlets operating from abroad are discreetly giving remote training to young people in Russia. It's a risky task in a country that ranks 162nd for press freedom worldwide.

title: The United Arab Emirates' triple game in Gaza
summary: While developing a strategic partnership with Israel, the United Arab Emirates are claiming to agree with the Arab position on a Palestinian state, and carefully publicize their providing of humanitarian aid in the Gaza Strip, writes historian Jean-Pierre Filiu.

title: The execution of four Canadians in China is a reminder of Beijing's stringent anti-drug laws
summary: The country is extremely tough on drug-related crime. A Frenchman, convicted in 2010 by a Canton court, is still on death row.

title: South Korea's top court reinstates PM Han as acting president
summary: South Korea’s Constitutional Court dismissed the impeachment of Prime Minister Han Duck-soo on Monday, reinstating him as acting president. The ruling comes as the court deliberates on the fate of suspended President Yoon Suk Yeol, whose attempted martial law declaration in December set off a constitutional showdown.

title: Bernie Sanders on tour in Denver: 'We will not allow America to become an oligarchy'
summary: The Vermont senator and leader of the progressive left wants to build a movement beyond the Democratic Party to encourage citizens to defend democracy.

title: Greenland: Usha Vance's highly controversial visit
summary: The wife of US Vice President JD Vance will visit Greenland for three days this week. The trip, made in a politically sensitive context, is seen as a provocation both on the island and in Denmark.

title: On the quest for the perfect dürüm, at Chez Mehmet in Paris
summary: Every week, a journalist discusses a place that made a lasting impression, like this restaurant in the 18th arrondissement of Paris specializing in dürüm döner kebab, the traditional form of the famous Turkish sandwich.

title: Sweden rebuilds its 'total defense' model, in which every inhabitant must be prepared
summary: 'Europeans, war and peace' (Part 1 of 7). Since the Ukraine invasion, the Scandinavian kingdom has been rebuilding the model developed after World War II, based on the principle that the army would not be enough to protect the country.

title: As Israel presses Gaza offensive, a journalist is killed and evacuation calls are issued
summary: Gaza's civil defense agency said an Israeli drone strike on Monday afternoon killed Hussam Shabat, who was working with Al Jazeera, near a petrol station in Beit Lahia.
